title.narrative: Strengthening the Resilience of our Islands and our Communities

description.narrative: Strengthening the Resilience of our Islands and our Communities to Climate Change (SRIC - CC)

title.narrative: SRIC Adaption Fund Cook Islands - Project Document

description.narrative: Strengthening the Resilience of our Islands and our Communities to Climate Change (SRIC - CC)
semi-independent political entity

1) Volume (Litres) of water storage capacity in communities affected by climate-induced water shortages 2) Number of households with enhanced capacity to reduce climate-induced disturbances in food supply through applying climate resilient agriculture and fisheries techniques 3) Number of households with access to enhanced health services and practices adapting to climate-induced health risks

comment.narrative:
Output1.1 Learning needs identification, resourcing and evaluating mechanism/process established by year 2
By end of year 4 of the programme, at least 100 government staff with responsibilities for CCA and DRR in the Pa Enua have received training, consistent with the creation of a learning needs mechanism/process. Output1.2 At least four relevant national and island level policy instruments, and coordination mechanisms addressing have integrated climate risk management. Output1.3 By year 3, CIMs observational and data management capacity is enhanced (network of weather stations and related data management system expanded)
By the end of the programme, climate early warning and information products are regularly received and applied by at least 100 gov officials and 1000 households in the Pa Enua.
Output2.1 By the end of the 3rd year, integrated climate change adaptation and disaster risk reduction action plans approved for each of the 11 inhabited Pa Enua, and harmonized with island development plans. Output2.2 By the end of the 3rd year at least 500 island stakeholders and key players have been trained in climate and disaster risk assessment and management involving both men and women in an equitable manner
By the end of the 3rd year, at least 50 initiatives to build capacity in climate and disaster risk assessment and management are funded by the small grants programme, and are completed successfully, involving both men and women in an equitable manner. Output3.1 By the end of the programme, at least 50 successfully completed initiatives to undertake climate change adaptation and disaster risk reduction at community or island level, involving equally both men and women Output3.2 By the end of the programme at least 750 households have increased capacity in applying climate resilient agriculture and fisheries practices in at least 5 islands (Aitutaki, Atiu, Manihiki, Mangaia and Mauke). Output3.3 By the end of the programme 6.6 M Litres of additional wate

Output1.1 The project have reached more than 100 participants on CCA and DRR in the Pa Enua through the Southern School Workshop, JNAP Validation Workshop, 3D Modelling workshop, 2 Basket of Resilience Workshops and the SRIC Project Platform Meetings each quarter. It is good to note that out of the 100 participants, a high percentage of females make up this number with approximately 70% being female and the rest male. Output1.2 The project is doing significantly well in achieving its target under this output. The implementation of a recommendation from the national CCA and DRM Policy review and development was completed in October 2015. This review allowed for mainstreaming CC and disaster risks into national policy frameworks including the NSDP (2016-2020) as well as strengthening the JNAP. The Revision of the Joint National Action Plan (JNAP) II for Disaster Management & CC is completed and planning to be tabled in the next Cabinet meeting planned for January 2017, project is requested to do a bit more editing before tabling with Cabinet. The NSDP was revised and launched in June 16th 2016, it takes into account the mainstreaming of CCA to all sectors of government as per MTE management response. Unlike the previous two NSDPs containing eight goals the new NSDP 2016 – 2020 focuses on sixteen strategic areas; welfare and equity, economy and employment, waste management, water and sanitation, infrastructure and ICT, transport and energy, health, education, gender and the vulnerable, agriculture and food security, environment and biodiversity, ocean, lagoon and marine resources, resilience and climate change, culture, population, and good governance law and order. Finally the, National DRM Plan- Emergency Management Cook Islands is currently being revised to include CRM. Output1.3 • The Geo Portal is already established and operational, this is managed by the Emergency Management Cook Islands Division of OPM.
• The CLEWS component had a slow start; the tender proce

By end of year 4 of the programme, at least 100 government staff with responsibilities for CCA and DRR in the Pa Enua have received training, consistent with the creation of a learning needs mechanism/process. Output1.2 At least four relevant national and island level policy instruments, and coordination mechanisms addressing have integrated climate risk management. Output1.3 By year 3, CIMs observational and data management capacity is enhanced (network of weather stations and related data management system expanded)
By the end of the programme, climate early warning and information products are regularly received and applied by at least 100 gov officials and 1000 households in the Pa Enua.
Output2.1 By the end of the 3rd year, integrated climate change adaptation and disaster risk reduction action plans approved for each of the 11 inhabited Pa Enua, and harmonized with island development plans. Output2.2 By the end of the 3rd year at least 500 island stakeholders and key players have been trained in climate and disaster risk assessment and management involving both men and women in an equitable manner
By the end of the 3rd year, at least 50 initiatives to build capacity in climate and disaster risk assessment and management are funded by the small grants programme, and are completed successfully, involving both men and women in an equitable manner. Output3.1 By the end of the programme, at least 50 successfully completed initiatives to undertake climate change adaptation and disaster risk reduction at community or island level, involving equally both men and women Output3.2 By the end of the programme at least 750 households have increased capacity in applying climate resilient agriculture and fisheries practices in at least 5 islands (Aitutaki, Atiu, Manihiki, Mangaia and Mauke). Output3.3 By the end of the programme 6.6 M Litres of additional water storage capacity installed on 10 islands (Atiu, Mangaia, Mitiaro, Palmerston, Aitutaki, Rakahanga, Manihik
Update is based on pending PPR to be submitted.

title.narrative: National Biodiversity Strategy in Cook Islands

description.narrative: National Biodiversity Planning to Support the implementation of the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) 2011-2020 Strategic Plan in Cook Islands (NBSAP).
The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Extent to which legal frameworks are in place for conservation, sustainable use, and access and benefit sharing of natural resources, biodiversity and ecosystems
Extent to which policy frameworks are in place for conservation, sustainable use, and access and benefit sharing of natural resources, biodiversity and ecosystems
Extent to which institutional frameworks are in place for conservation, sustainable use, and access and benefit sharing of natural resources, biodiversity and ecosystems
Extent to which capacities to implement national and local plans for Integrated Water Resources Management have improved
Extent to which capacities to protect and restore the health, productivity and resilience of oceans and marine ecosystems, have improved

This project is part of the second generation of Biodiversity Enabling Activities (BD EA) under the GEF. Cook Islands has been Party to the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) since 20 April 1993.
capital of a political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration

1. Number of sectoral planning frameworks that include measureable biodiversity conservation and sustainable targets with gender considerations.
2. Number of development frameworks that include inclusion of gender, youth and measurable biodiversity conservation and sustainable use targets

comment.narrative:
1. Biodiversity is part of the NSDP 2011-2015 under priority area six; however more recent information must be added for the next NSDP 2016-2020. All plans are aligned to this umbrella plan
2. Biodiversity is part of the NSDP 2011-2015 under priority area six; however more recent information must be added for the next NSDP 2016-2020. These will need to be measurable.

- By end of 2015, a multi-sectoral/multi- stakeholder working group is established and it completes the stock-taking exercise. - By end of 2015, national targets in response to the global Aichi Targets are developed. - Recruit the Lead Consultant to draft the NBSAP, the 5th National Report to the CBD and a brief review of the biodiversity planning process in Cook Islands. - By late 2016, the Cook Islands’ NBSAP is fully updated, it is in line with the guidance in the CBD Strategic Plan (2011 2020) and has been submitted to the CBD COP. - By late 2016, the Cook Islands’ NBSAP will be an inclusive document that also covers areas of society including gender and youth.

The recrutiment of the lead consultant, Dr Dave Butler was finalised and awarded on 18th April 2016. Dr. Butler and the Project Coordinator immediately commenced planning the NBSAP National Workshop in Rarotonga from 19 to 22 June 2016. Dr Butler arrived on the 12th June and departed on the 2nd July, after successfully holding the Outer Islands delegates Workshop on Monday 20th June and the National NBSAP workshop on Tuesday 21 June 2016.
Dr Dave provided the first draft of the 5th national report to the CBD on 26 September. The Technical groups to assist the lead consultant as per ProDoc were recruited. Group A- Environmental, economincs, finance and biodiversity mainstreaming (Te Ipukarea Society) Group B - Capacity Needs Assessment (Ms. Maureen Hilyard and Ms. Mathilda Tairea).
A draft capacity needs assessment was prepared and shared by the consultants in 2016. A half day Terrestrial and Marine working group workshop was conducted by Dr. Dave Butler. The purpose of the working group workshop was to develop action plans on species and ecosystem conservation for inclusion in the NBSAP Action Plan. The minutes from this workshop is well documents and available if interested.
The Draft 5th National Report to the CBD is expected to be finalised in December 2016. It is therefore planned that the final sections of the draft report will be completed by mid-jan 2017 by Dave Butler. The 2nd NBSAP Action Plan Draft report is in progress and is planned to be circulated for comments in 2017. Stocktake exercise is complete.

- By mid-2017, the national CHM is complete the kept up-to-date and has been improved; - By mid-2017a complete plan for implementing the NBSAP, including capacity, technology and finance needs assessment, has been produced and underpins NBSAP implementation. - Finalize the 2 working group reports as well as the 5th National Report - Finalize and launch the NBSAP

Quarter 1 Dr Dave Butler continued with the development and finalisation of the 5th National Report to the CBD and overall revised NBSAP document. The 5th NR was fine-tuned and revised in Q1 2017.
The Capacity Needs Assessment (Block B) report is near completion. A final draft report and action plan booklet has been received and reviewed by NES and Dr Butler. The outcomes of this document will be integrated into the final NBSAP document.
A bilingual promotional video was developed and produced by NBSAP project in conjunction with NES Education and Awareness team ad Varo Media. The promotional video is in two parts with the first highlighting the beauty an value of the environment and biodiversity and the second incorporating comments from the traditional leaders.
Quarter 2 The final NBSAP Workshop was held on the 14 - 16 July 2017. This workshop presented a draft NBSAP with a goal for the Workshop to be a working meeting to review and provide input into the Action Plan and implementation strategies sections of the new NBSAP. The project funded the participation of government and community representatives from the 5 southern group Pa Enua islands. The project was unable to secure participation in the workshop from the Northern Group Islands however post workshop, the consultant was able to have one on one meetings with representatives of 2 islands who happened to be on Rarotonga at the time and has received email input from a 3rd. While the workshop was very successful, there still remains some gaps in the marine and agriculture sections that require further input from stakeholders and the project is working with the various ministries and organisations to gather this. This means that a final draft will not be able to be circulated to stakeholders and UNDP until mid-late July.
The Capacity Assessment consultancy (Block B) carried out by Ms Maureen Hilyard and Ms Matilda Tairea was completed and submitted to the BSC. A presentation on this report was given during

title.narrative: Access to Benefit-Sharing (ABS) Nagoya Protocol in Cook Islands

description.narrative: Strengthening the implementation of the Nagoya Protocol on access to genetic resources and benefit sharing in the Cook Islands (Full Project)
The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Extent to which legal frameworks are in place for conservation, sustainable use, and access and benefit sharing of natural resources, biodiversity and ecosystems
Extent to which policy frameworks are in place for conservation, sustainable use, and access and benefit sharing of natural resources, biodiversity and ecosystems
Extent to which institutional frameworks are in place for conservation, sustainable use, and access and benefit sharing of natural resources, biodiversity and ecosystems
Extent to which capacities to implement national and local plans for Integrated Water Resources Management have improved
Extent to which capacities to protect and restore the health, productivity and resilience of oceans and marine ecosystems, have improved

title.narrative: ABS Nagoya Protocol in Cook Is

description.narrative: Strengthening the implementation of the Nagoya Protocol on access to genetic resources and benefit sharing in the Cook Islands (Medium SizeProject)
capital of a political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration

1. Number of ABS laws in compliance with the Nagoya Protocol; 2. Level of institutional and personnel capacity for implementation of the national ABS framework measured by the UNDP/GEF ABS Capacity Development Score

comment.narrative: 1. Earlier draft Act developed in 2005 but is non-compliant with the NP 2013 TK Act; 1. 43 out of a possible 75 = 57%

Quarter 1 and 2: - Emily Pierre was appointed as Project Coordinator on April 5th 2016; - A 2-day Inception Workshop (IW) was held on 11th & 12th May 2016 to launch the ABS project. The first day was an internal session between the NES Project Team and the UNDP mission from the Regional and Country offices. Over 20 stakeholders and interested parties attended the External session on the 2nd day of the IW to be briefed and understand the Project’s goals and objectives, work plans, review and define their roles and responsibilities, and also the related technical and managerial aspects. - In addition to the Inception workshop initial awareness of the project’s Nagoya Protocol and the ABS framework in the Cook Islands, further exposure increased via presentations at the following;
- Brilliant Resilient National Seminar in May - The National Biodiversity Strategic Action Plan workshop in June - Exhibitions for National Environment Week – Environment Expo
For Component 3, Implementing agency staff changes - Mrs Jenny Henry is the new Director for Matheson Enterprises (ME). She replaces Mr Ken Matheson as of 1st July. ME and its research & development partner have signed project agreements that has resulted in ME delivering material based on the ABS agreement but not part of the Nagoya Protocol Grant, and also have signed agreements for the production of material and technology transfer related to delivering products from the Access and Benefit bone and cartilage regeneration program. In addition ME has completed planning aimed at providing a framework for the implementation of key objectives relating to improving the Access and Benefit Sharing Agreement with Te Koutu Nui.
Quarter 3 and 4 Matheson Enterprises and Parnell have completed project agreements that have resulted in Matheson Enterprises delivering material based on the Access and Benefit bone and cartilage regeneration agreement. Rudimentary Datasheet recorded to enable a Prototype Material Expo

- The Policy Analyst was recruited in Q3 of the year after delays in identifying qualified consultants in country. They have completed a consultations and submitted a report on the finding from the initial consultation on Aitutaki. They plan to conduct the rest in early 2018. The Technical Specialist from the Global ABS project was approached to guide the policy and framework development for this project with the agreement to fund his travels to guide the local authorities on the layout and the information to be gathered on NP and ABS. A mission and workshop is planned for 2018.
The CIMPTECH/Matheson have procured the Mass Spectrometer as per target and it is envisioned to be in country in early 2018.

title.narrative: Ridge to Reef Approach in Cook

description.narrative: Full Size Project for Cook Islands; " Conserving Biodiversity and Enhancing Ecosystem Functions through a Ridge to Reef Approach in the Cook Islands"
capital of a political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration

Project Objective: 1. Overall framework in place for conservation in the Southern Group of the Cook Islands 2. Area of inhabited Outer Islands in Southern Group managed for BD conservation through Island Development Plans 2.1 Terrestrial 2.2 Marine 3. Tracking Tool IW1: Innovative solutions implemented for reduced pollution, improved water use efficiency, sustainable fisheries with rights-based management, IWRM, water supply protection in SIDS, and aquifer and catchment protection
Component 1: 1. Improved management effectiveness of Cook Islands Marine Park, as measured by GEF BD 1 Tracking Tool (METT) 2. National agencies responsible for PA management are effectively delivering PA management functions (as measured by the Capacity development indicator score for protected area system): 2.1 Systemic 2.2.Institutional 2.3 Individual 3. Updated and consolidated legal framework for management of the Cook Islands Marine Park (CIMP) and all other protected areas in the country 4. Consolidated management authority for protected areas in the Cook Islands 5. Management of protected area sites on islands in the Southern Group 6. % Area of Southern Group islands managed as Protected Areas (protected natural areas, community conservation areas, ra’ui sites) 6.1 Terrestrial 6.2 Marine (to the outer reef) 7. Improved management effectiveness of priority conservation zones, as measured by the GEF BD 1 Tracking Tool (METT): 7.1 Takitumu Conservation Area (Rarotonga) 7.2 Cloud Forest Nature Reserve (Rarotonga) 7.3 Manuae Wildlife Sanctuary / Marine Reserve (Manuae) 7.4 Moko Ero Nui Leeward Forest Reserve (Atiu) 7.5 Takutea Wildlife Sanctuary / Marine Reserve (Takutea) 8. Lagoon ecosystems are managed in a coordinated manner and with clear ecological conservation objectives 9. Funds available for management of Protected Areas, as reported in the GEF BD1 Tracking Tool – Financial Scorecard: 9.1 Non-governmental financing mechanisms 9.2 Government budget allocations 10. Conserva

comment.narrative:
Project Objective: 1. Cook Islands Marine Park (CIMP) declared as protected, but with no legal designation or active management 2.2.1. 0 2.2.2. 0 3. Limited local capacity exists for overseeing and monitoring of water quality in lagoons
Component 1: 1. METT score = 30 2.2.1 50% 2.2.2 47% 2.2.3 52% 3. Existing legislation for PAs is out-dated and incomplete: CIMP and Ra’ui systems have no legal standing; detailed regulations are not in place 4. Institutional authority for protected areas is spread among various agencies 5. 1 existing protected area site (Takitumu Conservation Area) is actively managed 6.6.1 2.8% 6.6.2 9.7% 7.7.1 64 7.7.2 26 7.7.3 12 7.7.4 26 7.7.5 29 8. Lagoons in the Cook Islands are not actively managed for conservation 9.9.1 US$23,800 9.9.2 US$63,750 10. Baseline TBD in year 1 of project 11.11.1. Baseline TBD in year 1 of project 11.11.2. Baseline TBD in year 1 of project 11.11.3. Baseline TBD in year 1 of project 11.11.4. Baseline TBD in year 1 of project 11.11.5. 420 individuals 11.11.6. 1,000 individuals 11.11.7. 428 individuals (Rarotonga); 125 individuals (Atiu) 11.11.8. 375 mature trees
Component 2: 1.1.1. 0 1.1.2. 0 2.2.1. NZ$339,554 2.2.2. NZ$406,701 3. Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) process depends on self reporting by developers 4. 13,245 hectares of natural forested area 5. Sedimentation and pollution (pesticides, herbicides, fertilizers, waste) have significant negative impacts on streams and lagoons in the country 6. Baseline TBD during year 1 of project 7. Less than 5 tourism businesses in the Cook Islands actively implement environmental management programs 8. 6 on-going projects in the Southern Group

End of Project Targets Project Objective: 1.1 million sq. km. of CIMP legally designated and actively managed, with dedicated staff implementing planning and coordination of the entire CIMP by end of year 2 2. By end of project: 2.1. 6 islands totalling 15,110 ha. 2.2. 6 islands totalling 16,174 ha. 3. Water quality improved through small demonstrations and monitoring mechanisms in place for project related indicators
Component 1: 1. METT score > 60 by end of project 2. By end of project: 2.1. 70% 2.2. 70% 2.3. 70% 3. Protected and Managed Areas Act drafted and enacted by end of year 2; detailed regulations for resource restrictions and PA management enacted by end of project 4. Marae Moana Office undertaking coordinated management of protected areas by end of project 5. Management plans for at least 15 protected area sites under implementation by end of project 6. By end of project: 6.1. 6.7% 6.2 12.3% 7. By end of project: 7.1 METT score >70 7.2 METT score >50 7.3 METT score >40 7.4.METT score >50 7.5 METT score >50 8. Aitutaki Lagoon Master Plan in place, with conservation zoning, goals and targets 9. By end of project: 9.1. US$523,800 9.2. US$148,750 10. No decrease in finfish populations by end of project 11. No net decline in population 11.7. No net decline in population 11.8. No net decline in forested area

EIAs for infrastructure development in or around PAs are subject to independent review, and development plans are adapted as necessary to conserve biodiversity 4. title.narrative: UN Joint Presence & Coordination in Cook Islands

description.narrative: After a study conducted in 2015 about Joint Presence Offices (JPOs) in the Pacific. The UN system agreed to establish JPOs in the Cook Island & Niue to be led by UN Coordination Officers for 3 years (2016-2018).

document-link.url: https://info.undp.org/docs/pdc/Documents/COK/UN JPO Cook Islands and Niue Prodoc with signed cover page.pdf

title.narrative: UN Joint Presence & Coordination in Cook Islands

description.narrative: United Nations agreed to establish a Joint Presence Offices and placing UN Coordination officer in the Cook Islands, this will contribute to the UN development system leadership and coordination.
capital of a political entity
capital of a political entity
policy, planning and administration
